item.name: Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee

item.title: A concurrent resolution supporting the goals and ideals of "National Sudden Cardiac Arrest Awareness Month".

item.name: Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee

item.text: Referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.
Passed/agreed to in House: On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.

At the conclusion of debate, the chair put the question on the motion to suspend the rules. Mr. Burgess objected to the vote on the grounds that a quorum was not present. Further proceedings on the motion were postponed. The point of no quorum was withdrawn.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Con. Res. 393.
Considered under suspension of the rules. (consideration: CR H8684-8685; text of measure as introduced: CR H8684)
Mr. Pallone moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.
Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR E1523)

summary.text: Expresses support for the goals and ideals of National Sudden Cardiac Arrest Awareness Month.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

Expresses support for the goals and ideals of National Sudden Cardiac Arrest Awareness Month.

bill.title: Supporting the goals and ideals of "National Sudden Cardiac Arrest Awareness Month".

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
